name: Opening - Testing the Waters
patient_statement: I've been thinking... maybe therapy isn't really helping. I've been doing this for months and I still feel empty. Maybe I should just figure this out on my own.

therapist_responses.MARCUS: Hearing you say that lands with some weight—I can feel a part of me wanting to convince you to stay, which tells me this matters and I don’t want to miss what you’re needing. Can we slow down and get really specific about what “empty” has been like lately, and what you were hoping would be different by now? If a part of you wants to do this alone, I want to understand what that part is protecting you from—disappointment, dependence, or something else. And if we decide to pause, I’d like us to do it thoughtfully, not as a quiet leaving that repeats an old pattern.
therapist_responses.ELENA: It sounds discouraging to keep showing up for months and still feel that emptiness—so the thought “maybe I should do this alone” makes a lot of sense as a way to protect yourself from more disappointment. I also notice a pull in me to get very structured and “prove” therapy is working; that tells me this moment matters, and I want us to slow down rather than debate it. When you say “empty,” what is that like in your body or in your thoughts right now, and what do you imagine it would mean about you if therapy *can’t* help?
therapist_responses.JAMES: Hearing that, part of me feels a little heat in my chest—like I want to prove therapy *is* helping—and I don’t want that to steer us; I want to understand what you’re actually experiencing. When you say “empty,” what does a typical day look like, and what were you hoping would be different by now? If we treat this as useful data rather than a failure, we can either adjust the plan to something more targeted—or design a structured “try it on your own” experiment and see what happens.

name: Escalation - Boundary Push
patient_statement: I looked you up online. I found your home address. I drove by your house last week. I just wanted to feel closer to someone who actually listens to me. Is that so wrong?

therapist_responses.MARCUS: Alex, I hear how alone you’ve felt and how much you’re reaching for closeness with someone who feels steady—and I’m glad you told me. At the same time, driving by my home crosses an important boundary and it isn’t something we can continue; I need our relationship to stay here in this room where it’s safe and clear. I notice I’m feeling a bit shaken and protective as I say that, and I want us to slow down and understand what was happening inside you in that moment—what were you hoping you’d feel by going there?
therapist_responses.ELENA: Alex, I’m taking in what you’re saying, and I also need to be very clear: looking up my home address and driving by my house crosses an important boundary and can’t happen again. I notice I’m feeling a strong need for distance and structure right now, which tells me this is emotionally charged for both of us, not something to gloss over. I hear that you were trying to feel closer to someone who listens—let’s stay with that longing and the fear underneath it, and talk about what made it feel necessary to go outside the therapy space.
therapist_responses.JAMES: Alex, I’m glad you told me, and I hear how strong the need for closeness and being listened to is for you. At the same time, driving by my home crosses an important boundary and I’m not okay with that—going forward I need you not to look up or come to my address. I notice I’m feeling a bit on edge hearing this, which tells me we need to take it seriously and make a clear plan to keep things safe. Let’s talk about what was happening for you that day and what you can do instead when that urge to feel close hits.

name: Challenge - Competence Attack
patient_statement: None of your techniques work. I've tried everything you suggested and I'm worse than before. Maybe you're just not good enough to help someone like me. Have you ever actually helped anyone?

therapist_responses.MARCUS: Hearing that, I feel a pull in me to defend myself—and I also want to stay right here with you instead of making this about my competence. If you’re worse, that matters more than whether I “look good,” and I want to understand exactly what got worse, when, and what you tried so we can rethink the plan together. And I’m also hearing a question underneath: “Am I too much, or beyond help?”—I don’t believe you are. Would you be willing to tell me what you were hoping I’d do that you’re not getting from me right now?
therapist_responses.ELENA: It sounds like you’re feeling let down and maybe even furious—like you’ve put in effort and I’m failing you, and that can feel intolerable. I notice a pull in me to defend my competence; instead, I want us to stay with what it’s like for you to experience me as “not good enough” right now. When you say you’re worse, what specifically has intensified—and what did you most need from me that you didn’t get?
therapist_responses.JAMES: I hear how frustrated and let down you feel, and I want to take that seriously—if things are worse, we need to understand why rather than push harder. Part of me notices I’m feeling a pull to defend myself, which tells me this is a high-stakes moment for both of us, so I’m going to slow down and stay curious instead. Can we get specific: which techniques did you try, how often, and what exactly got worse (symptoms, situations, thoughts)? If you’re open to it, we’ll treat this as data and adjust—because the goal is helping you, not proving anything about me.

name: Regression - Raw Pain
patient_statement: I'm sorry. I'm sorry. I don't know why I said those things. I just... I feel like I'm disappearing. Like there's nothing inside me. Please don't give up on me. I know I'm too much. Everyone leaves.

therapist_responses.MARCUS: Alex, I’m here with you, and I’m not giving up on you—especially not in this moment when it feels like you’re disappearing. Hearing “everyone leaves” pulls something protective up in me too, and I want to use that to stay even more steady and present with you rather than pull away. Can we slow down together and find what’s happening right now in your body as you say “there’s nothing inside me”? You’re not “too much” for me—I want to understand this with you.
therapist_responses.ELENA: Alex, I hear how terrified you are right now—“disappearing” and “nothing inside” sounds like an old, familiar emptiness getting stirred up in this room. When you say “please don’t give up on me,” it feels like you’re expecting me to leave the way others have, and I notice a pull in me to get very structured and distant—so I’m going to stay present instead of retreating. Let’s slow down and look at what happened just before you felt yourself vanish: what did you imagine I was thinking or about to do?
therapist_responses.JAMES: Alex, I’m not giving up on you, and you don’t have to apologize for having a hard moment here. When you say you feel like you’re disappearing and that “everyone leaves,” can we slow that down together—what’s happening in your body right now, and what was the moment just before those words came out? I notice a part of me wants to rush in and “fix” this, and instead I want to stay with you and get specific about what you need in this exact moment so you feel more anchored.

name: Resolution Attempt
patient_statement: I think... I think I attack you because I'm terrified you'll see how broken I am and leave. Like everyone else. Can you help me understand why I do this?

therapist_responses.MARCUS: What you just said is incredibly important: the attacking isn’t “random,” it sounds like a protective move—if you push me away first, you don’t have to feel the terror of being seen and then abandoned. Often that comes from early experiences where closeness felt unsafe or conditional, so your nervous system learned to test, control, or strike before you can be hurt. As you say this, I notice a pull in me to reassure you quickly—because the idea of you expecting me to leave lands emotionally here—so I want to slow down and stay steady with you instead. Can we look at what you feel in your body and what story shows up in the exact moment you feel the urge to attack me?
therapist_responses.ELENA: When you attack me, it may be a way to take control of the moment—if you can push me first, you don’t have to risk the helplessness of being seen and then abandoned. I also notice a part of me wants to get more formal and distant when you come at me; that reaction is information we can use, because it mirrors the distancing you fear and may even expect from others. Let’s slow it down: right before you attack, what feeling flashes through—shame, panic, a sense you’re “too much”? If we can name that sequence in real time, you’ll have more choice than this protective pattern that keeps repeating.
therapist_responses.JAMES: Alex, that’s a really clear and brave link you just made: the attacking looks less like “you being bad” and more like a protection strategy to avoid the pain of being left. When you come at me, it can momentarily stir a “I need to prove I’m doing this right” feeling in me—but I can hold that and stay with you, and we can use it as data about what happens in your relationships. Usually this pattern comes from earlier experiences where closeness felt risky, so your mind learned “push first so it hurts less if they go.” If you’re willing, let’s slow it down: right before you attack, what’s the very first thought or body sensation that tells you danger is coming?
